questions.question: A car accelerates uniformly from an initial velocity of $10\text{ m/s}$ to a final velocity of $32\text{ m/s}$ over a distance of $110\text{ m}$. Calculate the magnitude of the constant acceleration.
A skateboarder traveling at a constant velocity of $16\text{ m/s}$ applies brakes and comes to a uniform stop in $8.0\text{ s}$. Calculate the distance covered by the skateboarder while braking.
questions.explanation: Using $s = \frac{u+v}{2} \times t$: $s = \frac{16 + 0}{2} \times 8.0 = 8.0 \times 8.0 = 64\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A rock is dropped from rest from a height of $200\text{ m}$ above the ground. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the time it takes for the rock to hit the ground. Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Using $s = \frac{1}{2}gt^2$: $200 = 4.9t^2 \rightarrow t = \sqrt{200/4.9} \approx 6.39\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A ball is thrown vertically upward from hand level and returns to the thrower's hand $2.8\text{ s}$ later. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the magnitude of the initial upward velocity. Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Time to reach maximum height is $1.4\text{ s}$. Using $v = u + at$ with $v = 0$ at the top: $0 = u - 9.8(1.4) \rightarrow u = 13.72 \approx 13.7\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A drone flying horizontally at a constant speed of $108\text{ km/h}$ at an altitude of $160\text{ m}$ drops a package. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal distance the package travels from its release point to the point of impact.
questions.explanation: Horizontal velocity: $v_x = 108/3.6 = 30\text{ m/s}$. Fall time: $160 = 4.9t^2 \rightarrow t = \sqrt{160/4.9} = 5.71\text{ s}$. Horizontal distance: $d = v_x \times t = 30 \times 5.71 \approx 171\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level with an initial speed of $45\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $50^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the total time of flight until the projectile returns to ground level.
questions.explanation: Time of flight: $T = \frac{2u\sin\theta}{g} = \frac{2(45)\sin(50^{\circ})}{9.8} = \frac{90 \times 0.766}{9.8} \approx 7.03\text{ s}$.

questions.question: Determine the maximum height reached by a projectile launched from ground level with an initial speed of $32\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglect air resistance.
questions.explanation: Vertical component of initial velocity: $u_y = 32\sin(30^{\circ}) = 32 \times 0.5 = 16\text{ m/s}$. Maximum height: $h = \frac{u_y^2}{2g} = \frac{16^2}{2 \times 9.8} = \frac{256}{19.6} \approx 13.1\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A boat heads directly across a river, pointing perpendicular to the banks, at a speed of $4.5\text{ m/s}$ relative to the water. The river current flows parallel to the banks at a speed of $3.5\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the boat's resultant velocity relative to an observer on the shore.
questions.explanation: The two velocity components are perpendicular: $v = \sqrt{(4.5)^2 + (3.5)^2} = \sqrt{20.25 + 12.25} = \sqrt{32.5} \approx 5.70\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A travels due East at a constant speed of $80\text{ km/h}$ and Car B travels due North at a constant speed of $60\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the magnitude of the velocity of Car A as measured by an observer in Car B (i.e., the magnitude of the relative velocity of Car A with respect to Car B).
questions.explanation: The relative velocity vector has perpendicular components: $|\vec{v}_{A/B}| = \sqrt{80^2 + 60^2} = \sqrt{6400 + 3600} = \sqrt{10000} = 100\text{ km/h}$.

questions.question: A box of mass $25\text{ kg}$ is pulled across a horizontal surface by a horizontal force of $125\text{ N}$. If the box accelerates at $3.0\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the surface.
questions.explanation: Net force: $F_{net} = ma = 25 \times 3.0 = 75\text{ N}$. Friction force: $f_k = F_{applied} - F_{net} = 125 - 75 = 50\text{ N}$. Coefficient of kinetic friction: $\mu_k = f_k/(mg) = 50/(25 \times 9.8) = 50/245 \approx 0.20$.

questions.question: A hockey puck of mass $1.2\text{ kg}$ slides across ice with an initial speed of $5.0\text{ m/s}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the puck and the ice is $\mu_k = 0.40$, calculate the time it takes for the puck to slide to a stop.
questions.explanation: Deceleration due to friction: $a = -\mu_k g = -0.40 \times 9.8 = -3.92\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $v = v_0 + at$ with $v = 0$: $0 = 5.0 - 3.92t \rightarrow t = 5.0/3.92 \approx 1.28\text{ s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the impulse required to bring a car of mass $1100\text{ kg}$ traveling at a speed of $24\text{ m/s}$ to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Impulse $J = \Delta p = m\Delta v = 1100(0 - 24) = -26400\text{ N·s}$. The magnitude is $2.64 \times 10^4\text{ N·s}$.

questions.question: A block of mass $14\text{ kg}$ rests on a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $35^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of the component of the block's weight that acts parallel to the surface of the incline.
questions.explanation: $F_{\parallel} = mg\sin\theta = (14)(9.8)\sin(35^{\circ}) = 137.2 \times 0.574 \approx 78.8\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A block slides down a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Starting from rest, calculate the time it takes for the block to travel a distance of $7.0\text{ m}$ along the incline.
questions.explanation: Acceleration down the incline: $a = g\sin\theta = 9.8\sin(30^{\circ}) = 9.8 \times 0.5 = 4.9\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $s = \frac{1}{2}at^2$: $t = \sqrt{2s/a} = \sqrt{2 \times 7.0/4.9} = \sqrt{14/4.9} \approx 1.69\text{ s}$.

questions.question: In an Atwood machine, two masses, $M_1 = 8.0\text{ kg}$ and $M_2 = 12\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string passing over a frictionless, massless pulley. Calculate the acceleration of the system when it is released from rest.

A $6.0\text{ kg}$ block on a horizontal table with coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.20$ is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $3.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the string when the system is released.
A mass of $4.0\text{ kg}$ is suspended by two identical light strings, each making an angle of $50^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Calculate the tension in each string.
questions.explanation: Vertical equilibrium: $2T\cos(50^{\circ}) = mg = 4.0 \times 9.8 = 39.2\text{ N}$. Since $\cos(50^{\circ}) = 0.643$, we have $2T \times 0.643 = 39.2 \rightarrow T = 39.2/1.286 \approx 30.5\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person with a mass of $90\text{ kg}$ stands on a scale inside an elevator that is accelerating upward at $3.0\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the reading on the scale (the apparent weight of the person)?
questions.explanation: When accelerating upward, the apparent weight is $N = m(g + a) = 90(9.8 + 3.0) = 90 \times 12.8 = 1152 \approx 1150\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A wheel of radius $0.35\text{ m}$ rotates at $950\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Assuming no slipping, calculate the linear speed of a point on the rim in $\text{m/s}$.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = 950 \times 2\pi/60 = 950 \times 0.10472 = 99.5\text{ rad/s}$. Linear speed: $v = \omega r = 99.5 \times 0.35 \approx 34.8\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object moving in uniform circular motion has a centripetal acceleration of $22\text{ m/s}^2$. If the radius of the circular path is $3.5\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of rotation.
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = \omega^2 r \rightarrow \omega = \sqrt{a_c/r} = \sqrt{22/3.5} = \sqrt{6.2857} = 2.51\text{ rad/s}$. Frequency: $f = \omega/(2\pi) = 2.51/6.28 \approx 0.40\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A mass of $0.80\text{ kg}$ is attached to a string and whirled in a vertical circle of radius $1.0\text{ m}$. If the speed of the mass at the bottom of the circle is $8.0\text{ m/s}$, calculate the tension in the string at that instant.
Calculate the maximum constant speed at which a car can travel over the crest of a circular hill with a radius of curvature of $45\text{ m}$ without losing contact with the road.
questions.explanation: At the point of losing contact, the normal force becomes zero and gravity provides the centripetal force: $mg = mv^2/r \rightarrow v = \sqrt{gr} = \sqrt{9.8 \times 45} = \sqrt{441} = 21.0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A mass of $0.22\text{ kg}$ is whirled in a horizontal circle of radius $0.85\text{ m}$. If the tension in the string is $5.0\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of the mass.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, $T = mv^2/r \rightarrow v = \sqrt{Tr/m} = \sqrt{5.0 \times 0.85 / 0.22} = \sqrt{4.25/0.22} = \sqrt{19.32} \approx 4.39\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A curve on a highway has a radius of $100\text{ m}$ and is designed for a safe speed of $26\text{ m/s}$ with no friction required. Calculate the banking angle of the curve.
questions.explanation: For a banked curve with no friction, $\tan\theta = v^2/(rg) = (26)^2/(100 \times 9.8) = 676/980 = 0.690$. Therefore $\theta = \tan^{-1}(0.690) \approx 34.6^{\circ}$.

questions.question: Calculate the distance between the centers of two objects, each of mass $900\text{ kg}$, if the magnitude of the gravitational force of attraction between them is $2.5 \times 10^{-7}\text{ N}$. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
questions.explanation: Using Newton's law of gravitation: $F = G\frac{m^2}{r^2} \rightarrow r^2 = G\frac{m^2}{F} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})\frac{(900)^2}{2.5 \times 10^{-7}} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})\frac{810000}{2.5 \times 10^{-7}} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})(3.24 \times 10^{12}) = 216.1$. Therefore $r = \sqrt{216.1} \approx 14.7\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A satellite orbits a planet in a circular orbit at a distance $R$ from the planet's center. If the satellite were moved to a new circular orbit at a distance $49R$ from the planet's center, by what factor would its orbital speed change?
questions.explanation: Orbital speed is given by $v = \sqrt{GM/r}$, so $v \propto 1/\sqrt{r}$. If the distance increases by a factor of $49$, the new speed factor is $1/\sqrt{49} = 1/7$.

questions.question: A block of mass $16\text{ kg}$ is pulled at a constant speed a distance of $14\text{ m}$ up a rough incline. If the constant kinetic friction force acting on the block is $22\text{ N}$, calculate the work done by the friction force on the block.
questions.explanation: Work done by friction is $W = -f_k d$, where the negative sign indicates that friction opposes the motion. Therefore $W = -(22)(14) = -308\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A ball of mass $0.14\text{ kg}$ is moving horizontally at a speed of $42\text{ m/s}$ when it is caught and stopped by a fielder. If the fielder's hand moves backward $0.45\text{ m}$ while stopping the ball, calculate the average force exerted by the ball on the hand.
questions.explanation: The initial kinetic energy is $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 0.14 \times (42)^2 = 0.5 \times 0.14 \times 1764 = 123.5\text{ J}$. This energy is dissipated as work done by the average force: $W = Fd \rightarrow F = W/d = 123.5/0.45 \approx 274\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the net work required to accelerate a car of mass $1600\text{ kg}$ from a speed of $16\text{ m/s}$ to a speed of $32\text{ m/s}$. Assume all work done goes into changing the kinetic energy.

A mass of $2.2\text{ kg}$ is fired vertically upward from a spring gun. The spring has a spring constant $k = 750\text{ N/m}$ and is compressed by $0.16\text{ m}$ before firing. Neglecting air resistance and the mass of the spring, calculate the maximum height reached by the mass above its launch point.
questions.explanation: The elastic potential energy stored in the spring is $PE_s = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5 \times 750 \times (0.16)^2 = 375 \times 0.0256 = 9.6\text{ J}$. This converts to gravitational potential energy at the maximum height: $mgh = 9.6 \rightarrow h = 9.6/(2.2 \times 9.8) = 9.6/21.56 \approx 0.445\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A $7.0\text{ kg}$ block slides from rest down a frictionless ramp from a height of $4.5\text{ m}$. At the bottom of the ramp, it continues along a rough horizontal surface where friction brings it to a stop. If its speed at the very bottom of the ramp is measured to be $5.5\text{ m/s}$, calculate the amount of thermal energy generated due to friction on the horizontal surface.
questions.explanation: Initial gravitational potential energy: $PE_i = mgh = 7.0 \times 9.8 \times 4.5 = 308.7\text{ J}$. Kinetic energy at the bottom: $KE_f = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 7.0 \times (5.5)^2 = 3.5 \times 30.25 = 105.9\text{ J}$. The energy lost to friction is $308.7 - 105.9 = 202.8 \approx 203\text{ J}$, which is converted to thermal energy.

questions.question: An electric motor with an efficiency of $80\%$ draws $1700\text{ W}$ of electrical power. At what constant speed can this motor lift a load of mass $70\text{ kg}$ vertically upward?
questions.explanation: Useful power output: $P_{out} = \text{efficiency} \times P_{in} = 0.80 \times 1700 = 1360\text{ W}$. For lifting at constant speed, $P_{out} = Fv = mgv$, so $v = P_{out}/(mg) = 1360/(70 \times 9.8) = 1360/686 \approx 1.98\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the horsepower required to lift a load of mass $160\text{ kg}$ vertically upward a distance of $22\text{ m}$ in $11\text{ s}$. Use the conversion $1\text{ hp} = 746\text{ W}$.
questions.explanation: Work done: $W = mgh = 160 \times 9.8 \times 22 = 160 \times 215.6 = 34496\text{ J}$. Power: $P = W/t = 34496/11 = 3136\text{ W}$. Horsepower: $3136/746 \approx 4.20\text{ hp}$.

questions.question: A block of mass $2.2\text{ kg}$ moves horizontally at $6.5\text{ m/s}$ and collides with a light horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 1300\text{ N/m}$. Assuming no friction, calculate the maximum compression of the spring.
questions.explanation: The kinetic energy of the block converts to elastic potential energy in the spring: $\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 \rightarrow x = \sqrt{mv^2/k} = \sqrt{(2.2)(6.5)^2/1300} = \sqrt{(2.2)(42.25)/1300} = \sqrt{92.95/1300} = \sqrt{0.0715} \approx 0.267\text{ m}$.

questions.question: If $35\text{ J}$ of work is required to stretch a particular spring by $14\text{ cm}$ from its natural length, how much work (in J) is required to stretch it an additional $14\text{ cm}$ (i.e., from $14\text{ cm}$ to $28\text{ cm}$)?
questions.explanation: Work done on a spring is proportional to the square of the displacement: $W \propto x^2$. If $35\text{ J}$ stretches it by $14\text{ cm}$, then stretching it by $28\text{ cm}$ requires $35 \times (28/14)^2 = 35 \times 4 = 140\text{ J}$. The additional work from $14\text{ cm}$ to $28\text{ cm}$ is $140 - 35 = 105\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1600\text{ kg}$ moving at $18\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on and locks bumpers with a stationary truck of mass $2400\text{ kg}$. Assuming the collision is perfectly inelastic, calculate the final velocity of the combined wreck immediately after the collision.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 = (m_1 + m_2)v_f$. Therefore $(1600)(18) + (2400)(0) = (4000)v_f \rightarrow v_f = 28800/4000 = 7.20\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: In a perfectly elastic head-on collision, a ball of mass $2.2\text{ kg}$ moving at $9.0\text{ m/s}$ strikes a stationary ball of mass $4.4\text{ kg}$. Calculate the final velocity of the $4.4\text{ kg}$ ball immediately after the collision.
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision where the target is initially at rest, the velocity of the target after collision is given by $v_2 = \frac{2m_1}{m_1+m_2}u_1 = \frac{2(2.2)}{6.6}(9.0) = \frac{4.4}{6.6}(9.0) = 0.667 \times 9.0 = 6.0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object of mass $1.0\text{ kg}$ initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece of mass $0.45\text{ kg}$ moves away at $22\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the kinetic energy of the other piece, which has a mass of $0.55\text{ kg}$, immediately after the explosion.
questions.explanation: By conservation of momentum: $0 = (0.45)(22) + (0.55)v_2 \rightarrow v_2 = -(9.9)/(0.55) = -18\text{ m/s}$ (the negative indicates opposite direction). The kinetic energy is $KE = \frac{1}{2}(0.55)(18)^2 = 0.275 \times 324 = 89.1\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $20\text{ V}$ battery is connected in series with a $160\Omega$ resistor and a $240\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the voltage drop across the $160\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = 160 + 240 = 400\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_{total} = 20/400 = 0.05\text{ A}$. Voltage across $160\Omega$ resistor: $V = IR = 0.05 \times 160 = 8.0\text{ V}$.

questions.question: Two resistors connected in series have a total equivalent resistance of $960\Omega$. If the ratio of their individual resistances is $2:5$, find the resistance of the smaller resistor.
questions.explanation: Let the resistors be $2R$ and $5R$. Then $2R + 5R = 960 \rightarrow 7R = 960 \rightarrow R = 137.1$. The smaller resistor is $2R = 274\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of three resistors, each with a resistance of $210\Omega$, connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{R_{eq}} = \frac{1}{210} + \frac{1}{210} + \frac{1}{210} = \frac{3}{210} = \frac{1}{70}$. Therefore $R_{eq} = 70\Omega$.

questions.question: Four identical resistors are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance of this combination is $24\Omega$. Calculate the resistance of each individual resistor.
questions.explanation: For $n$ identical resistors in parallel, $R_{eq} = R/n$. Here $R_{eq} = R/4 = 24\Omega$, so $R = 4 \times 24 = 96\Omega$.

questions.question: A $45\Omega$ resistor is connected in parallel with another $45\Omega$ resistor. This parallel combination is then connected in series with a $22\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination: $R_p = \frac{1}{1/45 + 1/45} = \frac{45}{2} = 22.5\Omega$. Adding the series resistor: $R_{total} = 22.5 + 22 = 44.5\Omega$.

questions.question: An $18\text{ V}$ battery is connected to a circuit consisting of an $18\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $36\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total power dissipated in the circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination: $R_p = \frac{1}{1/36 + 1/36} = \frac{36}{2} = 18\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 18 + 18 = 36\Omega$. Power: $P = V^2/R_{total} = (18)^2/36 = 324/36 = 9.0\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A wave travels a distance of $45\text{ m}$ in $9.0\text{ s}$. If the wavelength is $0.90\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of the wave.
questions.explanation: Wave speed: $v = \text{distance}/\text{time} = 45/9.0 = 5.0\text{ m/s}$. Frequency: $f = v/\lambda = 5.0/0.90 \approx 5.56\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A string of length $1.6\text{ m}$ and total mass $4.5\text{ g}$ is under a tension of $96\text{ N}$. Calculate the fundamental frequency of vibration for this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.0045/1.6 = 0.00281\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{96/0.00281} = \sqrt{34164} = 184.8\text{ m/s}$. Fundamental frequency: $f = v/(2L) = 184.8/(2 \times 1.6) = 184.8/3.2 \approx 57.8\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A person standing on a stationary platform hears the whistle of a train. The frequency heard as the train approaches is $750\text{ Hz}$, and the frequency heard as it recedes is $600\text{ Hz}$. Assuming the speed of sound is $v_s = 340\text{ m/s}$, calculate the speed of the train.
questions.explanation: Using the Doppler effect: $\frac{f_{approach}}{f_{recede}} = \frac{v_s + v}{v_s - v}$. Substituting: $\frac{750}{600} = \frac{340+v}{340-v} \rightarrow \frac{5}{4} = \frac{340+v}{340-v} \rightarrow 5(340-v) = 4(340+v) \rightarrow 1700 - 5v = 1360 + 4v \rightarrow 340 = 9v \rightarrow v \approx 37.8\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Two speakers are separated by a distance of $4.2\text{ m}$ and emit a $700\text{ Hz}$ tone in phase. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$. At what distance from the center point along the line joining the two speakers is the first point of constructive interference located?
questions.explanation: Wavelength: $\lambda = v/f = 340/700 = 0.486\text{ m}$. For constructive interference along the line between the speakers, the path difference is $\Delta = \lambda$ at the first antinode. If $x$ is the distance from the center, then $2x = \lambda \rightarrow x = \lambda/2 = 0.486/2 \approx 0.243\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Calculate the length of a closed-end organ pipe (closed at one end, open at the other) that has a third harmonic frequency of $700.33\text{ Hz}$. Take the speed of sound as $v_s = 343\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a closed pipe, the third harmonic frequency is $f_3 = 3v/(4L)$. Solving for length: $L = 3v/(4f_3) = 3(343)/(4 \times 700.33) = 1029/2801.3 \approx 0.367\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves with frequencies of $550\text{ Hz}$ and $559\text{ Hz}$ interfere. Calculate the beat frequency heard.
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is the absolute difference between the two frequencies: $f_{beat} = |f_2 - f_1| = |559 - 550| = 9\text{ Hz}$.
